content: The District of Columbia National Guard Educational Assistance Program is added as Title II to the Act for the organization of the militia of the District of Columbia. This program includes a short title and findings. The District of Columbia National Guard is unique and differs from other National Guards due to its federalized status and special mission in the capital. The President of the United States commands the District of Columbia National Guard, which is trained for unique emergencies in the presence of the Federal Government. Most members live in Maryland or Virginia, leading to a decline in force compared to neighboring National Guards. The District of Columbia National Guard faces challenges in recruiting and retaining members, with neighboring states offering incentives that draw recruits away. Providing educational benefits could help reverse this trend and maintain necessary force levels. The District of Columbia National Guard may be impacted by neighboring states' incentives, affecting its readiness to respond to a terrorist attack on the US capital. SEC. 202 establishes the District of Columbia National Guard Educational Assistance Program. The Mayor of the District of Columbia, in coordination with the commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard, will establish a program to provide financial assistance to eligible National Guard members for higher education expenses. Eligibility is determined by the commanding general certifying completion of certain criteria. The Mayor of the District of Columbia, in coordination with the commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard, has established a program to provide financial assistance to eligible National Guard members for higher education expenses. Eligibility requires completion of initial active duty service, a written agreement to serve for at least 6 years, and not receiving a Reserve Officer Training Corps scholarship. To maintain eligibility, members must perform duty satisfactorily as certified by the commanding general. The District of Columbia National Guard offers financial assistance for higher education expenses to eligible members who have completed initial active duty service, agreed to serve for at least 6 years, and are not receiving a Reserve Officer Training Corps scholarship. Eligible members must be enrolled in an approved institution of higher education, seeking to earn 3-12 credit hours per semester, and maintain satisfactory progress in their course of study. SEC. 203. Treatment of assistance provided for higher education expenses to eligible members of the District of Columbia National Guard who have completed initial active duty service and agreed to serve for at least 6 years. Financial assistance for members of the District of Columbia National Guard can be used for tuition, fees, books, and laboratory expenses. The assistance can be up to $400 per credit hour, not exceeding $6,000 per year. The Mayor can adjust the amount or limit participants if funds are insufficient. Members of the District of Columbia National Guard can receive financial assistance for education in addition to other assistance provided by law. Failure to fulfill service obligations may result in repayment requirements under title 37, United States Code. SEC. 204. ADMINISTRATION AND FUNDING OF PROGRAM. The Mayor, along with the commanding general of the District of Columbia National Guard and approved institutions of higher education, will develop policies for the program. Institutions of higher education are not required to change admissions policies for National Guard members. Funding for the program will be provided through appropriations to the District of Columbia. The Mayor can accept funds from Federal agencies and donations for providing assistance under the program. The term 'approved institution of higher education' in this title refers to an eligible institution that participates in student financial assistance programs and agrees to use funds to supplement, not replace, other aid for members of the District of Columbia National Guard. Financial assistance can be provided to eligible Guard members for instruction starting on or after January 1, 2013.
